title: Drumpellier Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Chris Upson / Monkland Canal, Drumpellier Country Park
images.caption: Monkland Canal, Drumpellier Country Park

images.title: Richard Webb / Drumpelier Country Park
images.caption: Drumpelier Country Park. What looks like a former field between a disused railway, and beyond the railway some rough woodland on an old colliery site, and the A752. A large area of old industrial land and woodland is now managed as a country park.

images.title: BJ Smur / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Source of the Bishop Burn. This spring gives rise to the Bishop Burn which in ancient times formed the boundary between the lands of the Archbishopric of Glasgow and the Monklands.

images.title: James Allan / Drumpellier houses
images.caption: Drumpellier houses. Private housing estate built in the 1950s beside Drumpellier golf course.

images.title: Elliott Simpson / The Visitor Centre at Lochend Loch, Drumpellier Country Park
images.caption: The Visitor Centre at Lochend Loch

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Lochend Loch, Drumpellier Country Park
images.caption: Lochend Loch on a sunny autumn day in 2008

description: Explore 500 acres of lowland heath, mixed woodlands, lochs and open grassland in this pretty country park located between Glasgow and Airdrie. You can follow the woodland paths to Lochend Loch and Woodend Loch before enjoying a stroll along the Monkland Canal which runs through the southern end of the park.  The park also contains a Visitor Centre, Cafeteria, Peace Garden and Nature trails. National Cycle Network number 75 runs along the southern edge of the park and there is another cycle path running through the park up to the loch. The park is located just to the west of Coatbridge very near to Blairhill railway which is a good point of access.
